title: Welcome to website1
description:
Welcome to our new blog, website1. We hope you enjoy 
reading what we have to say!

title: assignment1
description: A short description of the post.
contents:
Functions
Create a function that will return the sum of 2 numbers.


add <- function(a,b){
  return(a+b)
}

add (3,2)


[1] 5

Create a function that will return the mean of a vector of numbers fed to it.
A sample vector of values is provide here to help.


mynumbers <- sample(1:100, 10)

mymean <- function(vec){
  return(mean(vec))
}

mymean(mynumbers)


[1] 47.6

Now, expand on the function you made above, and instead of just returning the number, have it return the sentence:
"The mean is ___" where the blank is the calculated result.


mymean <- function(vec){
  return(paste("The mean is", mean(vec)))
}

mymean(mynumbers)


[1] "The mean is 47.6"



#load the data to use for the rest of the assignment questions
flights <- nycflights13::flights



Using the flights dataset from the package nycflights13 loaded in the above cell, create a function that filters the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport (column name origin).


filterairport <- function(df,airport){
  return(df[df$origin==airport,])
}

flights %>% filterairport("EWR")


# A tibble: 120,835 x 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
 2  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
 3  2013     1     1      555            600        -5      913
 4  2013     1     1      558            600        -2      923
 5  2013     1     1      559            600        -1      854
 6  2013     1     1      601            600         1      844
 7  2013     1     1      606            610        -4      858
 8  2013     1     1      607            607         0      858
 9  2013     1     1      608            600         8      807
10  2013     1     1      615            615         0      833
# â€¦ with 120,825 more rows, and 12 more variables:
#   sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>,
#   flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>,
#   air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>,
#   time_hour <dttm>

Similarly, using the flights dataset, create a function that:
filters the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport (column name origin), and then
aggregates the results by airline (carrier) to show how many flights each airline has from that airport.


getnumflightsforairport <- function(df,airport){
  return(df[df$origin==airport,] %>% group_by(carrier) %>% count())
}

flights %>% getnumflightsforairport("EWR")


# A tibble: 12 x 2
# Groups:   carrier [12]
   carrier     n
   <chr>   <int>
 1 9E       1268
 2 AA       3487
 3 AS        714
 4 B6       6557
 5 DL       4342
 6 EV      43939
 7 MQ       2276
 8 OO          6
 9 UA      46087
10 US       4405
11 VX       1566
12 WN       6188

Similarly, using the flights dataset, create a function that:
filters the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport (column name origin), and then
filter to only include flights longer than a specific number of minutes (air_time), and then
aggregates the results by airline (carrier) to show how many flights of that length each airline has from that airport.


getnumflightsforairportlongerthantime <- function(df,airport,time){
  return(df[df$origin==airport,] %>% filter(air_time>time) %>%  group_by(carrier) %>% count())
}

flights %>% getnumflightsforairportlongerthantime("EWR",124)


# A tibble: 12 x 2
# Groups:   carrier [12]
   carrier     n
   <chr>   <int>
 1 9E        175
 2 AA       3363
 3 AS        709
 4 B6       4271
 5 DL       1025
 6 EV       9153
 7 MQ        200
 8 OO          4
 9 UA      36825
10 US       1150
11 VX       1552
12 WN       3330

Plotly charts
Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a bar chart showing the breakdown of flights by airline that originate from JFK airport (origin) and are more than 400 minutes in length (air_time).


result <- flights %>% getnumflightsforairportlongerthantime("JFK",400)

plot_ly(
  x=result$carrier,
  y=result$n,
  name="JFK flight",
  type="bar"
)

Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a bar chart showing which destination airports (dest) have the most flights with durations of over 400 minutes (air_time).


results <- flights %>% filter(air_time>400) %>% group_by(dest) %>% count()
plot_ly(
  x=results$dest,
  y=results$n,
  type="bar",
)

Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a donut chart showing the share of flights each airline has for flights with a destination of Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu.


results<-flights %>% filter(dest=="HNL") %>% group_by(carrier) %>% count()
results %>% plot_ly(labels=~carrier,values=~n) %>% add_pie(hole=0.6)

Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a scatterplot chart for flights with a destination of Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu, that shows the relationship between the departure delay (dep_delay) and arrival delay (arr_delay).


results <- flights %>% filter(dest=="HNL")

results %>% plot_ly(x=~dep_delay,y=~arr_delay)
